title: we likely need to keep some mention of postgresql 8.2 around to have nominal redshift support

labels.name: wontfix / out of scope
labels.description: something we decided we aren't doing, for whatever reason

labels.name: regression
labels.description: something worked and was broken by a change

labels.name: near-term release
labels.description: addition to the milestone which indicates this should be in a near-term release

body:
### Describe the bug

I believe there is a regression of https://github.com/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/issues/5698 in 2.0.0

I get the below error after updating from 1.4.46 and have confirmed it present in 2.0.0 - 2.0.5.post1
```
UndefinedObject: unrecognized configuration parameter "standard_conforming_strings"
```

The logic added in  https://github.com/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/commit/415ddce1e3b429bdc1180c5b5f7750a08d226525
does not appear to be present in 2.0.0

It appears to have been removed in https://github.com/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/commit/db08a699489c9b0259579d7ff7fd6bf3496ca3a2

as seen in 
![Screenshot 2023-03-07 at 8 18 23 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4827852/223449134-3003f53c-3629-4e8d-85e7-64bf80a33bd8.png)



### Optional link from https://docs.sqlalchemy.org which documents the behavior that is expected

_No response_

### SQLAlchemy Version in Use

2.0.5post1

### DBAPI (i.e. the database driver)

psycopg2

### Database Vendor and Major Version

Redshift 1.0.46987

### Python Version

3.10

### Operating system

OSX

### To Reproduce

```python
import sqlalchemy
from sqlalchemy.orm import sessionmaker
from sqlalchemy import text

connection_string = 'postgresql+psycopg2://<redacted username>:<redacted url encoded password>@<redacted db hostname>:<redacted port>/<redacted database>'

redshift_engine = sqlalchemy.create_engine(connection_string, echo=False, pool_recycle=120, pool_pre_ping=True)

redshift_session = sessionmaker(bind=redshift_engine)

tmp_session = redshift_session()
tmp_session.query(text("SELECT * from my_schema.my_table limit 10")).all()
```

### Error


### Additional context

Downgrading to 1.4.46 has provided a workaround
